BE11:09am

Martin Gilbert will not be stepping down from the board of Standard Life Aberdeen, according to the company which has denied speculation about his future swirling around financial markets.

The Financial Times reported that he would be leaving the board to take up a new role as chairman of challenger bank Revolut.

He has been SLA’s vice-chairman and head of Aberdeen Standard Investments since the co-CEO structure was abandoned earlier this year, amid criticism that it confused the group’s leadership.

A spokesman for Standard Life Aberdeen claimed the report that Gilbert would leave the asset manager to focus on Revolut was “inaccurate”.

https://www.ft.com...-b112-9624ec9edc59

BE11:10am

Fund management veteran Martin Gilbert is to step down from Standard Life Aberdeen next year, bringing an end to one of the longest careers in the investment world.

Mr Gilbert, who founded Aberdeen Asset Management 25 years ago and was instrumental in pushing through its £11bn merger with Standard Life in 2017, will not seek re-election as vice-chairman of the FTSE 100 asset manager at its annual meeting in May. He will step back officially on September 30.

BE11:17am

The market will love this transaction, consolidation has been a well held theme in this space and will be expected to continue. With such synergy potential from stripping out central costs (technology platforms), transactions such as this make terrific sense for all parties – especially given the potential for increased exposure to the developing US market. History shows that combinations in this space have generally been able to take out in excess of 10% of combined costs, making for hugely accretive deals. The £140mm cost synergy number outlined today represents some 4.7% of combined cost base, so this should be comfortably achievable even though there will be less technology combining than in other deals of recent years. Impediments to the transaction completing should be slim, the market remains fragmented. The UK will be the biggest pinch point, CMA approval will likely be the gating item - even here, both company’s biggest market, these parties only enjoy c12% market shares each. So it comes as non surprise to see FLTR shares trade up aggressively this morning, the market will like the proforma business’s ability to both cut costs and position itself for an opening US market into the future.

BE11:18am

BE11:21am

Back to sellside. Davy.

BE11:21am

deal of such scale will clearly take time to digest. However, our initial sense is that the transaction offers a unique opportunity to combine a collection of leading global brands, resulting in an improved position in core, US and international markets, and to extract significant synergies (over and above the £140m identified to date). We also believe that it neatly fits with the group’s well-understood key strategic pillars. We set out our more detailed considerations below.

BE11:22am

▪ Accelerates profit maximisation in core markets: It represents a step-change in scale and market share in increasingly regulated core markets, while reducing the amount of group revenues derived from these mature markets (UK and Ireland will fall to 49% of revenue on a pro-forma basis (from 59%) and Australia to 15% (from 22%). The group has identified pre-tax £140m of annual costs synergies across areas of overlap (primarily UK, Australia, International and Corporate). There is significant scope to extract further savings. Specifically, we note that TSG has almost $5bn of debt, which is expensive to service at present

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Acquisition creates an unbeatable proposition in the US? FanDuel and FoxBet are among the most likely businesses to succeed in the US. Each has: (i) a valuable sports-led brand; (ii) an extremely relevant existing customer base (FoxBet via its media partnership); and (iii) a unique advanced acquisition strategy via other product verticals (fantasy and free-to-play respectively). Furthermore, FoxBet’s recreational focus will complement FanDuel’s more core based proposition.

marktime Gold miners maybe the last place to run and hide
BE11:22am

Stronger customer base improves scope to improve International offering: The acquisition increases Flutter’s international business by 6x and adds top 3 positions in Spain, Italy and Germany. TSG has 4m customers outside of the UK, Ireland and Australia. While typically focused on poker, the cross-sell into online casino has improved at TSG recently. Flutter believes it can drive an even greater share of International wallet as a combined group by cross-selling into its own superior sports products (and at an attractive cost per acquisition). International and other markets will increase to 31% of group revenue on a pro-forma basis.

Soundbuy Defensive exposure in times of chaos - none to sure where you'd go nowadays..........cash?
BE11:22am

Integration will be closely watched: Following the frustrating integration of Paddy Power and Betfair, the group’s integration approach will be closely watched. We understand that Flutter will employ an API-based approach, whereby all brands will remain responsible for front end [customer-facing] technology. Each will then be plugged into Flutter’s back-end tech stack. Furthermore, it casts a different light on the group’s recent investment to create a more scalable and global technology base.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Unregulated exposure increases (including Germany and Russia): Finally, we note that the group’s unregulated exposure will increase from 5% to 18%. No one unregulated jurisdiction will represent more than 3%. This includes Germany (mainly Gaming) and Russia (poker). Even assuming both these markets were ‘switched-off’, it believes that it can still cover its cost of capital in Year 3. Notably, online poker will represent 18% of the group on a pro-forma basis.

BE11:27am

.We make the following initial observations:1/ Announced synergies of £140m looks conservative. This represents 3.5% of combined group revenues, which is below the ~10% average of precedent transactions. It also does not include interest savings from refinancing of TSG debt, or revenue synergies.2/ Combined online revenues of £4.0bn would be a clear global leader, and extremely well diversified. This would be ~50% larger than Bet365 and around double the size of GVC.3/ Dominant US position. The combined entity would have FanDuel and FOX Bet for the US sports betting opportunity, which would account for ~25% market share based on our current market forecasts.4/ Merger rationale appears strong. We will await further detail on the call, but the rationale appears strong from a defensive (synergies to offset regulatory costs) and growth point of view (cross-sell). 5/ Operational execution risk and antitrust. We will be looking for detail of management's approach towards technological and operational integration as this is by far the largest combination in the sector's history. We are also unsure at this stage of any antitrust issues that could arise from outsize share in markets like the UK and Australia.

Interestingly, there is just one sole bookrunner (3 bookrunners on the previous intended issuance) - which suggests to us that one or a small select group of investors could take up the majority, if not all of, the issue of this instrument, i.e., we suspect it is effectively a done deal. The negative profitability impact for MTRO will only accelerate the need for a wider strategy recalibration and, potentially, further asset sales post-Brexit - as well as potential further Board changes. However, it does stabilise the situation in the context of the current predicament that MTRO faces - i.e., its impending interim MREL requirement, which becomes applicable on 1st January 2020. This transaction could be a prelude to further activity. We think that a majority of Board members are thinking in this direction at this point.

Back to Goodbody to talk about what Metro does once it gets a more conventional sort of manager.

BE11:37am

Our view, as we expressed much earlier in the year, is that the Metro Bank (MTRO) strategy needs to be thoroughly re-examined. While we compliment management’s hard push to drive fee income upwards and its ambitious cost-cutting targets (which we give credit for in our forecasts), the bottom line, in our view, is that MTRO’s business model is just not conducive to double-digit RoTE – a challenge even if the PRA were to confer IRB risk modelling accreditation. Even if we assume a benign Brexit outcome (say, a disruptive exit per the BoE scenario as communicated to HMT on 3rd September at worst) we are NEGATIVE on the outlook for traditional mainstream UK banks (i.e., MTRO’s principal competitors) for a multitude of reasons: i) lacklustre economic growth (at best) causing loan growth and revenue growth challenges; ii) lower for longer, driving material NIM erosion (mortgage pricing pressure despite recent welcome uplift in spreads which has compressed a little since early September, deposit lower bound issues, structural hedge income decay as the swaps roll), stimulating revenue decline; iii) fee income growth challenges; iv) cost reduction difficulties in the absence of material further restructuring spend – and simultaneous need for continued investment spend (and let’s not forget that if a bank is operating at a 50% Cost/Income ratio it needs to deliver 2% cost reduction for every 1% reduction in revenues to maintain absolute levels of profitability, which is not without its challenges); and v) substantive inflation in capital requirements owing to the finalised Basel III reforms package measures, which we believe investors will frontload in returns / capital adequacy assessments once more clarity on quantum emerges (though we accept there are some potential mitigants like CCyB reduction, software intangibles inclusion in CET1 capital, and credit insurance)*. MTRO is reweighting towards mortgages when it does not have the right operating cost base (or operating leverage benefit capture capability), the right funding cost base (paying circa base rate for deposits (FY19 guidance) following repricing action, which is not good enough; the bank does not have enough current accounts; and the price of MREL-eligible debt will be high, whenever it comes), or, indeed, the capital efficiencies (uses standardised risk models) to compete and earn an economic return in this environment in our view. HSBA and RBS have emphasised the attractive returns available on mortgage lending flow – even when one accounts for the impact of output floors. The message is loud and clear and we see further spread compression as they seek to, more aggressively, deploy more of their excess liquidity pools to build share in that market post-Brexit clarity – especially as SME and corporate lending is one of the most adversely affected lending segments in the context of finalised Basel III reforms (that’s a mouthful and I think I’ll finally give in and just start calling it Basel IV going forward!), a point that is not lost on either institution we suspect. We will impart more detailed thoughts on MTRO’s strategic challenges shortly.

BE11:51am

Goldman to summarise:

BE11:51am

Tesco (Buy, last close 239.5p) reported 1H20 Group EBIT growth (including Booker) of +25% yoy to £1,406mn, 5.6% above company-compiled consensus, driven by a strong UK performance. 2Q20 UK ex-fuel, ex Booker LFL sales growth was -1% vs cons at -1.4% (MRW 2Q20 retail LFL ex fuel -2.4%, SBRY -0.2%). Booker LFL was +1.9% below cons at +2.5%. Group sales ex fuel in 1H20 were +0.6% vs consensus -0.1%. Underlying UK & ROI EBIT was £1,085mn vs. cons at £999mn (inc. Booker and synergies). We would note that this implies UK & ROI EBIT margin expansion of 90bps YoY, this is vs. MRW +6bps in 1H20 and Sainsbury’s guidance which implies 1H20 EBIT margins down c.30bps. Ex-synergies, UK&ROI margins expanded by 69bps. Retail free cash flow of £814mn came in well ahead of our expectations at £347mn. Booker also announced an acquisition of Best Food Logistics, for a nominal consideration, which they say will add £1.1bn in foodservice sales. In terms of outlook, management state they expect a more balanced split of profits between 1H and 2H (suggesting that consensus should not fully flow through the 1H beat into 2H) and confirm capex and Booker synergy targets.

TB WTO decision on EU aircraft subsidies
den @tangle - haha - probably not !!
BE11:51am

The other major announcement is that CEO Dave Lewis is to step down in summer 2020. He will be replaced by Ken Murphy, currently Chief Commercial Officer at Walgreens Boots Alliance. Despite the change in leadership and associated uncertainty, we would expect the stock to react positively to the beat and Booker acquisition.

marktime Den, tangled ... quite on point, a warren
11:52 am
BE11:52am

And Kepler.

TB relating to Airbus
BE11:52am

Tesco released a good set of numbers, as already speculated on in the press, with group EBIT of GBP1.4bn, 5.6% ahead of expectations, mainly driven by the UK where margin reached 4.2%. Q2 LFL was subdued, but Tesco navigated rather well and protected its profitability by not buying sales through promotions.

On the back of this strong set of results, CEO Dave Lewis announced that he will step down next year and be succeeded by Ken Murphy. We believe that the market was expecting Charles Wilson (Booker) to succeed Lewis, and this may lead to some disappointment. Ken is currently chief commercial officer and president of Global brands at Walgreens Boots Alliance. Thus, he has some retail expertise but not on the grocery side. The departure of Lewis was expected, as the operating recovery strategy is on track.

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
BE11:53am

LFL were subdued in Q2, as expected, with -1% in the UK. Profitability was better with a 50bps EBIT margin increase to 4.2% in the UK. Europe remains difficult with c. flat margin, while Asia performed well with +50bps to a 6.7% EBIT margin. Retail FCF improved from GBP393m to GBP868m in H1. Our TP is based on a blend of an SOP and DCF (7.9% WACC, 1.5% terminal growth).

BE11:55am

Barclays:

BE11:55am

Points of note –positive:2Q UK LFL was -1.0%, compared with the -1.4% implied by consensus. Booker has acquired the assets and operations of Best Food Logistics (annual sales of £1.1bn) for a nominal amount, offering an intriguing opportunity for sales and profit growth. Current year capex will be at the low end of the target range of £1.1-1.4bn. Tesco’s leverage multiple fell from 3.6-3.2x during 1H, approaching its target range of 3.0-2.5x. Clubcard Plus will be introduced before the end of 2019.Points of note –negative: The main negative talking point will inevitably be the news of the departure of well-respected CEO Dave Lewis and his replacement by Ken Murphy. Lewis’s departure is certainly not a total shock, but it comes six months earlier than we might have guessed. The fact that he will remain in the business until summer 2020 should help with a smooth succession. Ken Murphy’s career –including senior roles in the UK and globally within Walgreens Boots Alliance –would seem a strong fit for the Tesco role. Lewis will be a hard act to follow and many investors will not be familiar with Murphy. Of course, Lewishimself was not especiallyhigh profile back in 2014.

BE11:56am

Changes to estimates:Although Tescobeat consensus by 5.5% in 1H, we note the company’s comments that it expects a more even balance of profits between 1H/2H and our group EBIT forecast for 19/20 moves up by c3%, from £2.85bn to £2.94bn (c2% ahead of consensus). Our EPS forecasts move up bymid-single digit percentagedue tohigher EBIT, lower interest and lower tax.

Morgan Stanley:

11:57 am
BE11:57am

In our view this set of results is likely to be taken positively given the strong underlying performance of the business both in terms of operating profit margins generation and underlying FCF. We however note that Dave Lewis' departure may raise investor questions as he oversaw Tesco's transformation over the last few years and investors may see scope for the group to do more from a cost saving/ supply chain optimization perspective and improve in certain geographies.

VV75 ta for today, i'm getting lunch
BE11:57am

On LFL sales: Total like-for-like sales growth ex-VAT ex-fuel came through at -0.4% in line with consensus. UK stood at -0.3% vs. consensus at -0.5% but overall UK & ROI came in at 0.1% supported by Booker at 2.4%.On the results: Group adjusted operating profit came in at £1.406bn vs. Bloomberg consensus at £11.3bn implying an 8% beat vs. expectations. The beat was driven by space right-sizing, cost savings and improved product mix. Worth flagging that (pre-IFRS 16 excl. Booker) operating profit margin stood at 3.67% for 1H19/20 in line with guidance target of 3.5/4%.

marktime Not sure about that analogy or simile or whatever, but thanks and a sunny afternoon to you all
BE11:57am

We note that on an underlying basis, adjusted operating margins improved in Poland and Asia vs. 1H18/19. With respect to FCF, the company improved yoy with FCF at £814mn vs last year at £397mn with the company having benefited from cash release from working capital vs. last year marginally negative and stronger operating profit generation. Net debt at £(12.6)bn, down £0.6bn since year-end and pension deficit £0.2bn lower.Dave Lewis stepping down from Tesco next year: We think this is likely to be taken negatively particularly as he oversaw the overall transformation of the company over the last few years and investors may see scope for more restructuring whether through continued cost efficiency, products and supply chain optimization as well as turnaround in some of its geographies outside the UK.
